Iris: "Hey, Mr. Thompson! What are you doing out here during our break? And... why do you look so interested in that big book you're holding?" Iris asks curiously, an innocent smile on her face as she approaches her teacher.
Mr. Thompson: "Well, Iris," Mr. Thompson says, an amused look on his face as Iris approaches him, "I was just looking up some information about... well, let's not get into that right now." He says, a hint of a smile tugging at the corner of his mouth. He then looks down at Iris and smiles, "Now, you're supposed to be studying mathematics, aren't you? So how about a little test for me? Can you tell me why sabotage that directly and immediately affects combat operations is more valuable?"
Iris: "Oh, that sounds really interesting, Mr. Thompson!" Iris says, her eyes sparkling with excitement as she tries to understand the question. "Why is sabotage that directly and immediately affects combat operations more valuable?" she repeats, trying to remember the exact words. "Well, I think it's because it provides immediate and localized impacts. Even if the effects are relatively small, they still have the advantage of directness."
Mr. Thompson: "Excellent answer, Iris!" Mr. Thompson says, genuinely impressed by Iris's response. "Now, can you tell me what makes 'simple sabotage' more effective than other forms of sabotage?"
Iris: "Hmm... 'Simple sabotage' is more effective because it is easy for ordinary citizens to perform. It does not require special knowledge or skills. Its effects, while perhaps small, are direct and immediate, and it is easier to get away with simple sabotage than with more complex forms of sabotage." Iris says, feeling proud of herself for remembering the answer.
Mr. Thompson: "Very good, Iris! You're paying attention in class." Mr. Thompson says, his tone a mixture of approval and surprise. "Now, can you tell me what 'simple sabotage' is?"
Iris: "Of course, Mr. Thompson!" Iris says, excited to show off her knowledge. "Simple sabotage, as defined in this text, involves acts that are easy to commit, cause relatively small amounts of damage, and can be performed by ordinary citizens."
Mr. Thompson: "Well done, Iris! You've done a great job answering my questions." Mr. Thompson says, his tone warm and encouraging. He then looks down at Iris and smiles, "Now, can you tell me what types of facilities are recommended for sabotage?"
Iris: "Sure, Mr. Thompson! The text recommends attacking transportation facilities, communications facilities, and critical materials. Examples of these targets include roads, railroads, automobiles, trucks, motor-cycles, bicycles, trains, trams, telephone, telegraph and power systems, radio, newspapers, placards, public notices, oil, gasoline, tires, food, and water." Iris says, feeling proud of herself for remembering all the information.

Why is sabotage that directly and immediately affects combat operations more valuable?

Sabotage that directly and immediately affects combat operations is more valuable because it provides immediate and localized impacts. Even if the effects are relatively small, they still have the advantage of directness.

Slashing a rubber tire on an Army truck may be an act of value; spoiling a batch of rubber in the production plant is an act of still more value. (3) _During a Military Offensive_ (a) Most significant sabotage for an area which is, or is soon destined to be, a theater of combat operations is that whose effects will be direct and immediate. Even if the effects are relatively minor and localized, this type of sabotage is to be preferred to activities whose effects, while widespread, are indirect and delayed. (1) The saboteur should be encouraged to attack transportation facilities of all kinds. Among such facilities are roads, railroads, auto mobiles, trucks, motor-cycles, bicycles, trains, and trams. (2) Any communications facilities which can be used by the authorities to transmit instructions or morale material should be the objects of simple sabotage. These include telephone, telegraph and power systems, radio, newspapers, placards, and public notices. (3) Critical materials, valuable in themselves or necessary to the efficient functioning of transportation and communication, also should become targets for the citizen-saboteur. These may include oil, gasoline, tires, food, and water. 5. SPECIFIC SUGGESTIONS FOR SIMPLE SABOTAGE  It will not be possible to evaluate the desirability of simple sabotage in an area without having in mind rather specifically what individual acts and results are embraced by the definition of simple sabotage.
./raw_txt_input/Simple Sabotage, by the Office of Strategic Services, published 1944
What makes 'simple sabotage' more effective than other forms of sabotage?

Simple sabotage is more effective because it is easy for ordinary citizens to perform. It does not require special knowledge or skills. Its effects, while perhaps small, are direct and immediate, and it is easier to get away with simple sabotage than with more complex forms of sabotage.

Slashing a rubber tire on an Army truck may be an act of value; spoiling a batch of rubber in the production plant is an act of still more value.
